author: Kumar Buradikatti
text:
As many as 1,800 singers from six States with six different linguistic backgrounds collectively sang 108 devotional Kannada songs for six hours at the Sri Guru Raghavendra Mutt, Mantralayam, Andhra Pradesh, on Wednesday.

The performance that was inaugurated by Sri Subudhendra Tirtha, head and chief administrator of Sri Guru Raghavendra Mutt, around 12.30 p.m., and ended by 6.30 p.m., earned an entry in the Telugu Book of Records. All the devotional songs were on Lord Anjaneya. The performance was organised by Dasa Sahitya Project of the Mantralayam mutt.

The artists came from New Delhi, Maharashtra, Odisha, Telangana, Andhra Pradesh and Karnataka.

The maximum number of singers, 996, was from Andhra Pradesh, followed by Karnataka (458) and Maharashtra (241). Most of the singers were women. Keyboard, mridangam, tabla and violin were used during the performance.

“We are excited. We do not know Kannada. But we practised the Kannada songs with the help of the Devanagari script and performed well at the event,” Anjali from Mumbai said.

‘14 years of practice’

“We have been practising Dasa Sahitya for the last 14 years. We are glad that our 40-year-old Bhajan Mandali is part of a world-record performance now,” said Geetha, another participant.

Singers from six States rendered devotional songs in Kannada at Mantralayam
title: They sang their way to a record
